page.title: 15Life as a Gamekeeper
page.content: {Mrs Graves}and her husband, a {gamekeeper,}live at{Ranscombe Farm, which lies north of Cuxton. Mrs Graves says that their incubators hold ten thousand pheasant eggs each. They hatch the eggs for other people as well as for their own Shoot. They expect about 50% of the eggs to hatch. Their quietest period is between February and May. When the eggs begin to hatch, by the third week in May, they work twenty four hours a day until the season ends on 1st February. Pheasants may be shot from October on. The Gamekeeper works for a syndicate and the people who go shooting are called "Guns". The "Guns" are retired people, farmers and local business men. A Gamekeeper works hard, often going in the six thousand acres of woods at night to look for{poachers}or rising early to check the chicks.
